beginner.clue: The big 55-foot boat they traveled in

standard.clue: 55-foot vessel that carried the Corps up the Missouri

advanced.clue: Lewis's primary upstream transport, capable of carrying 12 tons

terms.definition: A large, flat-bottomed boat designed for river travel, equipped with sail, oars, and tow rope
terms.funFact: The keelboat had a cannon mounted on the bow and could carry 12 tons of supplies!

beginner.clue: Smaller boats like big canoes

standard.clue: Smaller flat-bottomed boats used alongside the keelboat

advanced.clue: French term for the expedition's auxiliary flat-bottomed craft

terms.definition: A long, narrow flat-bottomed boat, larger than a canoe, used on rivers
terms.funFact: The expedition had two pirogues -- one red and one white!

beginner.clue: The name for their group of explorers

standard.clue: Short for Corps of Discovery -- their official name

advanced.clue: Military term for this unit of volunteer soldiers and explorers

terms.definition: A group of people working together on a special mission; the expedition was the Corps of Discovery
terms.funFact: The full name was the 'Corps of Volunteers for North Western Discovery'!

beginner.clue: The flat, open grassland they crossed

standard.clue: Treeless grasslands stretching endlessly west

advanced.clue: Ecosystem Native peoples managed with prescribed burning

terms.definition: Vast, flat grasslands stretching across the middle of North America
terms.funFact: Native Americans used controlled fires to manage the prairie and attract buffalo herds!

beginner.clue: Huge animals with thick fur that roamed the grasslands

standard.clue: Animals so numerous they 'darkened the plains'

advanced.clue: Bison herds managed by Indigenous fire practices for millennia

terms.definition: American bison -- massive herd animals that once numbered in the tens of millions
terms.funFact: Clark wrote the herds were 'so numerous they darkened the plains' -- some herds had millions of animals!

beginner.clue: A sample of a plant or animal to study

standard.clue: Scientific sample collected and sent to Jefferson

advanced.clue: Material evidence of undocumented species for classification

terms.definition: A sample of a plant, animal, or mineral collected for scientific study
terms.funFact: Lewis sent a live prairie dog all the way to President Jefferson in Washington!

beginner.clue: Making friends and agreements with other groups

standard.clue: The art of building relationships between nations

advanced.clue: Jefferson's political strategy underlying the 'scientific' expedition

terms.definition: The practice of conducting negotiations and building relationships between nations
terms.funFact: Jefferson personally designed the peace medal ceremonies Lewis and Clark would use!

beginner.clue: A big meeting with tribal leaders

standard.clue: Formal gathering for diplomatic exchange with Native chiefs

advanced.clue: Ceremonial protocol Jefferson designed for asserting sovereignty

terms.definition: A formal meeting between leaders to discuss important matters
terms.funFact: At each council, Lewis gave a long speech, handed out medals, and demonstrated his air gun!

beginner.clue: Native people who welcomed the Corps for winter

standard.clue: Agricultural nation at the center of the Plains trade network

advanced.clue: Hub of a vast continental trade network predating European contact by centuries

terms.definition: A Native American people living along the Missouri River in present-day North Dakota
terms.funFact: The Mandan had been trading with Europeans since 1738 -- they weren't 'undiscovered' at all!

beginner.clue: The Shoshone woman who helped guide the expedition

standard.clue: Young Shoshone interpreter whose brother was chief

advanced.clue: Lemhi Shoshone woman whose presence signaled peaceful intentions to western tribes

terms.definition: A Lemhi Shoshone woman who joined the expedition as an interpreter and guide
terms.funFact: Sacagawea carried her baby on her back for thousands of miles across the continent!

beginner.clue: When extreme cold hurts your skin

standard.clue: Cold injury common at Fort Mandan in minus 45 degrees

advanced.clue: Tissue damage from temperatures Lewis recorded at -45 degrees Fahrenheit

terms.definition: Injury to body tissue caused by exposure to extreme cold
terms.funFact: At Fort Mandan, temperatures dropped to -45F -- so cold that whiskey froze solid!

beginner.clue: Carrying boats and supplies overland

standard.clue: 18-mile overland haul around the Great Falls

advanced.clue: Grueling evidence that Jefferson's hoped-for water route did not exist

terms.definition: The act of carrying boats and supplies overland to bypass an obstacle in a waterway
terms.funFact: The Great Falls portage took 24 days to cover just 18 miles -- with cactus, rattlesnakes, and grizzly bears!

beginner.clue: A very large and dangerous bear

standard.clue: Fearsome bear Lewis called 'most tremendous looking'

advanced.clue: Ursus arctos horribilis -- a species entirely new to American science

terms.definition: A large North American brown bear, known for its size and ferocity
terms.funFact: A grizzly once chased Lewis into the Missouri River! He wrote it was 'a most tremendous looking animal.'

beginner.clue: A tool for figuring out where you are using stars

standard.clue: Navigation instrument for measuring star positions

advanced.clue: Precision instrument for determining latitude from celestial observations

terms.definition: A navigation instrument used to measure the angle between a star and the horizon to determine position
terms.funFact: Lewis's celestial readings created the first accurate map of the American West!

beginner.clue: Sacagawea's people who had the horses they needed

standard.clue: Mountain nation that provided the critical horses

advanced.clue: Lemhi band whose chief was Sacagawea's long-lost brother

terms.definition: A Native American people of the Rocky Mountain region
terms.funFact: When Sacagawea recognized Chief Cameahwait as her brother, she ran to him and threw her blanket over him, weeping!

beginner.clue: Sacagawea's brother, the Shoshone chief

standard.clue: Chief who turned out to be Sacagawea's brother

advanced.clue: Lemhi Shoshone chief whose family reunion made the expedition possible

terms.definition: Chief of the Lemhi Shoshone and Sacagawea's brother, who provided horses for the mountain crossing
terms.funFact: Without Cameahwait's 29 horses, the expedition would have been stranded in the Rockies!

beginner.clue: The mountain line separating rivers east from west

standard.clue: Continental ____: boundary between east- and west-flowing waters

advanced.clue: Geographic boundary that disproved Jefferson's theory of an easy water route

terms.definition: The Continental Divide -- the line of mountain peaks separating rivers that flow east from those flowing west
terms.funFact: Crossing the Divide proved there was no easy water route to the Pacific -- Jefferson's main hope was wrong!

beginner.clue: Boats they carved from logs to travel rivers

standard.clue: Dugout craft the Nez Perce taught them to build

advanced.clue: Vessels constructed using Indigenous fire-hollowing techniques

terms.definition: A narrow boat, pointed at both ends, propelled by paddling
terms.funFact: The Nez Perce taught the Corps to hollow logs with fire -- much faster than using axes!

beginner.clue: The big river that led them to the Pacific

standard.clue: River system that carried them to the coast

advanced.clue: Major waterway navigated using Nez Perce geographic intelligence

terms.definition: A major river flowing from the Rocky Mountains to the Pacific Ocean
terms.funFact: The Columbia's rapids were so dangerous that the Corps nearly lost everything running them!

beginner.clue: Coastal people who were expert fishers

standard.clue: Pacific Northwest nation with superior fishing technology

advanced.clue: Maritime culture whose engineering Lewis openly admired

terms.definition: A Native American people of the Pacific Northwest coast, known for their fishing expertise
terms.funFact: The Chinook's fishing weirs could catch hundreds of salmon -- far more than any European method!

beginner.clue: When everyone got to choose where to camp

standard.clue: Democratic decision that included York and Sacagawea

advanced.clue: Extraordinary act of inclusion decades ahead of legal recognition

terms.definition: A formal expression of choice; at Fort Clatsop, everyone voted equally -- including York and Sacagawea
terms.funFact: York (an enslaved man) and Sacagawea (a Native woman) voted 60 years before the 15th and 19th Amendments!

beginner.clue: Clark's two-word journal entry used almost every day

standard.clue: Clark's signature journal phrase, meaning 'we kept going'

advanced.clue: Clark's laconic daily summary -- perhaps the most repeated phrase in the journals

beginner.clue: The official name of their exploring group

standard.clue: The expedition's official military designation

advanced.clue: The formal name Jefferson gave this unit of volunteer soldiers

beginner.clue: The huge flat grassland in the middle of America

standard.clue: Vast treeless grassland stretching west of the Missouri

advanced.clue: Continental grassland ecosystem managed by Native fire practices

beginner.clue: What the peace medals promised to tribal leaders

standard.clue: The message engraved on Jefferson's silver medals

advanced.clue: The diplomatic promise on medals that asserted American sovereignty

beginner.clue: The wooden fort they built for winter

standard.clue: Winter quarters built near the Mandan villages

advanced.clue: Cottonwood fort where the expedition spent five months gathering intelligence

beginner.clue: Sacagawea's baby, born at Fort Mandan

standard.clue: The youngest member of the expedition, born February 1805

advanced.clue: Sacagawea's son, whom Clark nicknamed 'Pomp' and later educated

beginner.clue: Latin for 'unknown land' -- what lay beyond Fort Mandan

standard.clue: 'Unknown territory' -- the unmapped land west of Fort Mandan

advanced.clue: Cartographic term for the 2,000-mile blank on American maps

beginner.clue: Lewis's words describing the amazing Great Falls

standard.clue: How Lewis described the Great Falls of the Missouri

advanced.clue: Lewis's Romantic-era description of the Great Falls, reflecting Sublime aesthetics

beginner.clue: Where Sacagawea found her brother -- they were 'fortunate'!

standard.clue: Named for the incredible luck of finding Sacagawea's brother

advanced.clue: Named by Lewis for the extraordinary coincidence of the Shoshone reunion

beginner.clue: The mountain ridge separating rivers flowing east from west

standard.clue: Mountain boundary between Atlantic and Pacific watersheds

advanced.clue: Hydrological boundary whose crossing disproved the Northwest Passage theory

beginner.clue: The scary mountain path through the Bitterroots

standard.clue: Ancient Nez Perce route through the Bitterroot Mountains

advanced.clue: The Nez Perce trail that nearly ended the expedition in starvation and snow

beginner.clue: Clark's excited words when he first saw the Pacific!

standard.clue: Clark's famous journal entry upon spotting the Pacific

advanced.clue: Clark's triumphant exclamation, actually misspelled as 'Ocian in view!'

beginner.clue: Their winter camp near the Pacific Ocean

standard.clue: Winter quarters on the Pacific coast, named for the local tribe

advanced.clue: Pacific winter camp chosen by democratic vote, where the journals were compiled
